comment.author: 22584609@N02
comment._content: ah...here is my baby :) I love this building. fantastic, genuine design !

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/artursikora] That is one fairly large baby, Artur! But delighted to feel the love for it...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 56799663@N05
comment._content: Hi NLI, do you guys have any pictures of what was there before Liberty Hall was rebuilt? Or of the crescent of buildings behind the Custom House (before the train line was build through or before Bus Arás was build?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/caracalla] These are some we have here on Flickr. Or you could try searching in our catalogue by place name, e.g. Beresford Place...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:
Tall building with only two lifts.
Memories of waiting in there to talk with assorted union folk who were trying to prevent me from working.
Nice views from up there though.

comment.author: 7517351@N05
comment._content: It looked great when it was built. Back before the grey paint and silver tinted windows that were later added. :)

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: A blight on the landscape of the city, it sticks out like a sore thumb, the only people who had the gall to insult the magnificent Customs House nearby were the Reds in the unions! (tongue in cheek!!!)  Seriously, I never liked it and thought that the planners who permitted it deserved to be made live next to it for the rest of their naturals!

comment.author: 31536722@N00
comment._content: It looks so shiny and new compared to its present state. It must have caused quite a stir in Dublin at that time.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
What a shame they build that.
So many lovely old neighbourhoods ruined for ever by big boring silver glassy concrete blocks of horrid.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hab3045] A "block of horrid" is a great expression! May borrow that...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 56911765@N04
comment._content: How come every time Ireland does modernity we get it so spectacularly wrong?

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/concorps] Because it is so easy to get modernity wrong... because rather often everything about modernity is wrong!
I have not seen (m)any (high rise) buildings build after the 1950s that are even close to looking good.
